Value: <Your TOS Text>
Note: Organisations should have User Guidance (sometimes Security Procedures or SyOPs) and this is an ideal place to reference and remind users of this [guidance](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/managing-deployed-devices/advising-end-users)

Value: Block addition of a managed account as secondary account (in-session)
Note: This will prevent users with multiple corporate accounts accessing them together in the same userspace. If your users hold secondary higher privileged accounts (PAW or similar) this will prevent data blending between them in a single user profile.

Value: Do not display the AI introduction screen during sign-in
Do not display the Gemini introduction screen during sign-in

Setting: See the README for details on Enrollment

Value: Do not allow users in this organisation to enrol new devices (or to re-enrol existing ones)
Note: See the README for details on Enrollment

Value: Require users to enroll device
Note: If a device is already enrolled into the OU then this setting will prevent a user from accessing the device if it is not already enrolled.

Value: Default browser behavior
Note: Whilst this is the default setting it is worth noting that this should be set to the organisations requirements and there is nothing inherently insecure about Manifest V2 extensions if managed well.

Value: Enable Quick Unlock PIN and Fingerprint. See Device Security Guidance [enterprise Authentication Policy](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/infrastructure/enterprise-authentication-policy). If enabling Ephemeral Mode this option is overridden with password/hardware token only.

Enable Quick Unlock PIN and Fingerprint. See Device Security Guidance [enterprise Authentication Policy](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/infrastructure/enterprise-authentication-policy). If enabling Ephemeral Mode this option is overridden with password/hardware token only.
Disable PIN Auto Submit on the lock and login Screen + User Override not allowed
Note: This is the Google Default option however administrators may wish to allow auto-submit.

Value: Disallow Incognito Mode
Note: If you are blocking users from signing into personal Google Accounts via `Sign in to secondary accounts` set this to Block. Otherwise set to allow incognito mode

Value: Prevent remote support connections from enterprise admins
Note: Organisations should review this setting as it might be appropriate for end user devices to have this enabled. We recommend disabling this for users and devices that have [higher privilege or access] (https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/principles-for-secure-paws/reduce-attack-surface#section_4)

Value: Data collection is never active
Note: Disable anonymised URL data being sent to Google for search and browsing enhancements.

Value: Never allow the use of built-in developer tools
Note: There are some legitimate use-cases for developer tools but these should be permitted on an individual basis. Note that this setting controls the browser's web developer tools and not ChromeOS Developer mode.

Value: Disable adding new profiles
Note: This will prevent users from adding secondary or personal accounts to their Chrome browser.

Value: Block multiple sign-in access
Note: This will prevent users from adding a secondary or personal account and be able to fast switch between them.

Value: Block users from signing in to or out of secondary Google Accounts
Note: This will remove the ability for users to access secondary work or personal accounts. Read the note settings for details

Value: Do not allow users to use Instant Tethering
Note: Organisations should review this setting based on their allocation of mobile devices to end users but we recommend this is disabled by default and enabled by exception

Value: Crosh
Note: Administrators should review the system apps users should need. By default we recommend disabling the ChromeOS Shell (Crosh)

Setting: Idle settings - Lock screen on sleep or lid close
Value: Lock Screen
Note: This behavior should be set by default however we are explicitly setting it

Value: Do not allow read and write access to external storage devices
Note: This setting when disabled will allow an administrator to set an allow list within the OU. It is recommended to configure this setting to disable in the parent OU and consider a managed bypass list based on OU/Security Groups/Individual users dependant on how you manage your removable media.

Value: Do not allow any site to request access
Note: By default this should be set to disabled in the root OU with exceptions made via this setting (allowed URLs) and the 'WebUSB API allowed devices' device hardware allow list.

Value: <set this per your allowed device ids>
Note: When working with the 'WebUSB API' setting above provides a hardware list of allowed USB devices which can use the WebUSB API.

Value: Do not allow any site to request serial ports via the Web Serial API
Note: By default this should be set to disabled in the root OU with exceptions made via this setting (allowed URLs) and the 'Web Serial API allowed devices' device hardware allow list.

Value: <set this per your allowed device ids>
Note: When working with the 'Web Serial API' setting above provides a hardware list of allowed serial devices which can use the Web Serial API.

Value: Do not allow sites to request read access to files and directories
Note: By default this should be set to disabled in the root OU with exceptions made via this setting (allowed URLs).

Value: Do not allow sites to request write access to files and directories
Note: By default this should be set to disabled in the root OU with exceptions made via this setting (allowed URLs).

Value: Require verified mode boot for Verified access
Note: This setting applies to un-enrolled/BYOD devices only.

Value: Safe Browsing is active in the standard mode + Do not allow users to override this setting
Note: See the [Google Safe Browsing Website](https://developers.google.com/safe-browsing/) for details on safe browsing

Value: Disable sending extra information to help improve Safe Browsing
Note: This setting sends some system information and page content to Google servers for additional analysis. You should decide if this is something your organisation can permit. [Google Support on Safe-Browsing Data](https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/14225066)

Value: Block ads on sites with intrusive ads
Note: Non-intrusive apps meet standards against the [Better Ads Standards](https://www.betterads.org/standards/). Whilst not a direct security control may prevent malicious advertising and give a better experience to the end user

Value: Your organisation should review it's own policies on use of Generative AI and apply these settings as it sees acceptable. See [NCSC Website](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/guidance/ai-and-cyber-security-what-you-need-to-know) for details.
Block usage for virtual machines needed to support Linux apps for users
Note: Crostini is disabled by default in enterprise environments. When enabled it will allow a user access to an unmanaged Linux VM. See [ChromeOS](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/platform-guides/chrome-os) on NCSC Website under Crostini Apps.

Value: Disable VM command line access

Setting: Linux virtual machine backup and restore
Value: Disable Linux virtual machine backup and restore
Do not allow users to enable and configure port forwarding into the VM container
Prevent the user from using Android apps from untrusted sources
Disable SSH in the terminal system app
Allow Chrome Sync + Do not allow sharing of user credentials with family members
Apply all user policies when users sign into Chrome and provide a managed Chrome experience
Require verified mode boot for verified access
Note: This setting applies to enrolled ChromeOS Devices only. See [Enable Verified Mode for ChromeOS Devices](https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/7156268).

Value: Disable guest mode
Restrict sign-in to a list of users
Note: Use your configured domains to restrict sign-in to your organisation (i.e. *@yourcompany.co.uk or *@sales.yourcompany.co.uk)

Value: Use the domain name set below for auto-complete at sign-in
Note: Auto complete will enforce the use of the sign-in restriction. This will help when only certain users can access certain devices (such as a PAW)

Value: Do not erase local user data
Note: See README for details on User Data/Ephemeral mode

Value: Disable remote access connections from enterprise admins
Note: See User and Browser/Remote access/Enterprise remote support connections. Enabling this setting will allow administrators to connect to a device when there is no user logged in.

Value: Enable all OS reporting
Note: Reporting on all device data

Value: Enable all hardware information reporting
Note: Reporting on all device data

Value: Enable all telemetry reporting
Note: Reporting on all device data

Value: Enable tracking recent users
Note: Reporting on all device data
This is the Google default (3hrs) but can be set lower if needed

Value: Enable Inactive device notifications
Note: The sub-settings for this should be set to your organisations risk appetite on devices that have not connected

Value: Never send metrics to Google
Note: Do not pass data back to Google which may expose URLs or other data captured in Crash Logs generated.

Value: Enable device system log upload
Note: Enables logging of system logs for administrators to monitor. See (Remote log collection for ChromeOS devices)[https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/13739279]

Value: Prevent users from collecting a system-wide performance trace
Note: Remove users ability to generate a system log

Setting: Linux virtual machines for unaffiliated users
Value: Block usage for virtual machines needed to support Linux apps for unaffiliated user
Note: Crostini is disabled by default in enterprise environments. When enabled it will allow a user access to an unmanaged Linux VM. See [ChromeOS](https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/platform-guides/chrome-os) on NCSC Website under Crostini Apps.

Value: Prevent users of this device from using ADB sideloading
Note: This will prevent Android apps being sideloaded into the Android subsystem. See README for more details on Android Apps.

Value: ${ASSET_ID}
Note: We recommend setting a unique identifier to allow administrators to identify devices in other areas of their network

Value: Enable data access protection
Note: Disabling or allowing the user to choose this setting can leave organisations at risk of attack by if introducing malicious hardware see (Using Peripherals Securely)[https://www.ncsc.gov.uk/collection/device-security-guidance/policies-and-settings/using-peripherals-securely]. Organisations should consider the risks before disabling this feature or allowing a user to override the default state.

Value: Disable Bluetooth
Note: Disable BT by default but consider enabling in trusted areas for known devices or users where needed for trusted peripherals

Value: Allow users to perform TPM firmware updates
Note: Users should follow the guidance on how to update their TPM and ensure that any local documents are backed up prior to updating their device.

Setting: Redeem offers through Chrome OS registration
Value: Prevent users from redeeming offers through Chrome OS registration
Do not allow user to perform network packet captures

Setting: Allow EMM partners access to device management
Value: Disable Chrome management - partner access
Note: This setting should be disabled unless you have a configured EMM Console. See [Google Support on EMM for ChromeOS](https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/7532316)

Value: Do not allow managed guest sessions
Note: This will disable managed guest sessions on devices.
